newsitem.title: BOTSWANA: Commonwealth urges Africa to safeguard democracy.
newsitem.headline: Commonwealth urges Africa to safeguard democracy.

text.p: Britain's former colonies in Africa should be vigilant against a slide back to one-party states or military rule, Commonwealth Secretary General Chief Emeka Anyaoku told them on Monday.

Opening a Commonwealth roundtable on democracy and good governance in the Botswanan capital Gaborone, Anyaoku said: "It takes considerably more than the paragraphs of a constitution to secure an effective and lasting democracy."
"No ruling party can plausibly claim to be the sole conscience and the sole embodiment of the will of the people, let alone their only prophet," he added.
Anyaoku, whose own country Nigeria is one of the few in Africa still under army rule, said military regimes could not take root if civilians simply refused to cooperate with them.

Heads of state or government delegations were expected at the four-day roundtable from 18 countries, among them Botswana and South Africa, both models of democracy, and others with less enviable democratic records such as the Gambia, Sierra Leone and Swaziland.
Nigeria did not attend. The meeting also included a delegation from Mozambique which, though never under British rule, has joined the organisation.
